reviewText:
Does Adventure Capitalist need a review? Sure why not; I review everything else on Steam, lets get into it. As with most games like this, there are plenty of unfunny joke reviews that will fill up the front store page for this game so I'm hoping to beat the trend and give some points about the game.

First of all, Adventure Capitalist is a game, about, well capitalism. You are an investor setting out to make your fortune.  This game is very similar to the likes of Cookie Clicker, which first came to fame in 2010, is still a mega popular game today. You start off buying lemonade stands, each click on the lemonade stand generates money, with that money buy another stand, so on and so on. Eventually you have enough money to hire a manager for your lemonade stand. The manager acts as the clicker, so you can leave the game running (or close it down) and you will still generate money. You then work up to other investments following the same pattern, and no sooner have you started, you will soon be a millionaire.  With your millions you can also purchase upgrades to your investments, such as increasing profit by 3% or something similar.

This is where AC is different to other clicker games, you no longer actually need to spam click in order to make progress, since you have your managers working over time for you. What I really like about AC is that you can close the game down, and you will still be generating money, meaning you can let your funds mount up for a couple of days, log back in, spend it all, and watch your money roll in for a bit, then log out.

The UI is so brilliantly displayed, you can work your way around all the menus with ease, and you can find all of the information you could ever need either on the main screen or within 2 clicks.  Be warned, this game not only has highly addictive gameplay, the soundtrack is almost just as addictive. Once that song gets in your head, it just will not leave.

AC is not hard at all, it just seems to be a time-sink, and one that keeps you logging back in on a daily basis. You can see just by the amount of hours I have in this game already just how easy it is to loose yourself in a really simple game. I would say I am not in the game for longer than 15 minutes on a daily basis, but it does keep bringing you back just so you can see what made up number of money you have made over night.

The developers are always adding new content to this game as well; recently there was an update which allows you to continue making your fortunes on the moon! This runs along side your regular empire back on earth, meaning twice as many investments to manage and oggle at crazy sums of money.

Given that AC is a free to play game, you have no harm in trying it out. I would say that even if you just load it up every couple of days to check it out, you will still get a lot of enjoyment out of it. There is also an iOS version of the game, but unfortunately it does not link up with your game on Steam; that would of been just too good if it did. Maybe it's a potential possibility in the future.

I really strongly recommend AdVenture Capitalist; its a simple, yet horribly addictive game, that allows you to pop in and hour of the game with ease for ten minutes at a time. Play in small doses to get the full effect!

1) Stay away
2) Only recommended when on sale
3) Recommended
4) Highly recommended
5) This is a must play

Here's how the game works: you click on a lemonade stand to earn money from it, and you keep doing that until you have enough money to buy another lemonade stand. Then you keep doing it some more until you can afford the next investment, and you can buy managers to click on the investments for you so you don't have to keep the game open at all times. And that's good, because it means the game will continue earning money for you when it's not open. So basically, the game is an exercise in economical masturbation.

When you have enough money, you can reset to gain angel investors. Each one adds (at the start) 2% to your income, so if you have 50 your income is doubled, at 100 it's tripled, and so on. The standard strategy is to do your first reset at about 150 angels, and then to reset again every time you double them. Because of how they're generated, the more of them you have, the more money it takes to get the next one.

And therein lies the problem: you see, once you have enough angels, it takes years to double them, and then it will take more years to double them the next time. And you won't be anywhere close to earning the last achievement when that happens. Look through the game's discussion pages, someone ran the game with a robot for 7 million years and didn't get anywhere near the 20th achievement.

The developers are wilfully blind to this situation, and instead of fixing the game so that it's possible to get the achievements, they're adding more stuff that the game's not yet ready for. Like the moon, where you hit the same 5-years-to-double problem at a tiny fraction of the angels it takes on Earth, but the final investments you need cost orders of magnitude more than on Earth.

Of course, you can also spend real money to get perks within the game, as is the model for free to play games, but you're only delaying the inevitable - you will eventually hit the impossible to progress stage, and your money will literally have been thrown away for nothing.

Now if you'll excuse me, I have to go punish a watermelon.

reviewText:
AdVenture Capitalist is one of those games that shoves a somewhat uncomfortable fact in my face.  While I have played thousands of games, and love a deep story, a grand adventure, a puzzling challenge, I also love to make numbers go up.  From an RPG characters stats, to the DPS numbers of my WoW raiding days, increasingly large numbers have been a benchmark of my success and progress in games.

There have been other games that offer a tongue-in-cheek or sarcastic look at the min-max or stat ♥♥♥♥♥ approach to gaming.  Whether a wry look at the gaming culture such as Achievement Unlocked, or simple nods to number driven games such as Manugo in Rift, there is always a fine line between mocking the need to see numbers go up, and selling a product that, well, makes numbers go up.

I love games that are aware of that aspect of gaming, because it is important to acknowledge, and also because I want to see numbers go up.  The problem with games like AdVenture Capitalist however, is that there is no deep story, no grand adventure, just numbers going up, and I still keep playing.  This leads me to wonder if the numbers are really the most important part for me.  If this could be the case, let us figure out why.

When I was a young lad in the previous century, there were no video games.  That's right, they did not exist.  Once they did, however, they took off like wildfire, and arcades began springing up everywhere.  Arcades were so ubiquitous in fact, that at one point there were three of them in my bathroom.  Here's the thing though.  Every game back then was about one thing.  Numbers going up.  You could be eating ghosts  in Pac-Man, blowing rocks up in Asteroids, or flipping balls at a pinball machine, the only metric you had for success in any of those things was a number, a high score.  The bigger the better.  If your initials were at the top of the list, you had the biggest number, and that meant you were the best.

Today though, games have become interactive entertainment that surpass anything else for truly immersive journeys through fantastic worlds.  Amazing stories are told, and you can be the focal point of legends, with songs sung in 5.1 surround sound about your heroic deeds, and displayed in glorious 1080p.  I love those games as well, but I still have roots in the old-school patterns and numbers that video games started with.  So why AdVenture Capitalist?  Making numbers go up is how I learned gaming.  It's what we started with, its what I know.  What's your excuse?

I liked this game at first. I think it had great potential. But I can't give this a recommendation. Here is why:

The pros:

1) It can be quite fun watching your empire of lemonade stands grow. The game has some nice moments like when your lemonade stands suddenly become more profitable than your oil rigs and you start shifting your investments.

The cons:

1) Inconsistency between mobile and PC versions. In the beginning this was my biggest gripe with the game. On mobile you get a 2x boost on all your profits for watching an ad (or rather setting the phone down for 25 seconds until the awful ad is done plaing). There is no such thing on the PC version. This makes playing on PC incredibly slower. Like by a mile slower. Like I started on pc and mobile at the same time but on PC I'm not even close to where I was weeks ago with the mobile version. reviewText:
Here is one of the first Idle games I stumbled upon (same time as Clicker Heroes) and while I enjoyed the first 20 to 30 minutes it soon dropped off my gaming list as I found Clicker Heroes much superior when it came to gameplay". After a few weeks my motivation flared again tho once I unlocked certain things and gameplay sped up a bit. As of now I consider myself in late midgame (7000 lemon stands) and everything has slowed to a crawl. The moon which was supposed to renew my interest into the game has only helped to crush my motivation due to its slow pogression.

I put in enough hours in this free to play game to say its well worth your time IF you like this kind of games. Overall placing it in the genre I d give it a 6/10.

So...lets go into details.

This game is about DECISIONS
date:
you wont "play" this as you do other games of yours.


You start out with only a couple dollars and invest them into companies which can be as small as lemon stands and as big as oil companies. Each company has a "run-time" and will yield you some cash after its done. Lemon stands provide a low income but also have a low run-time so you spend some time clicking the bar in order to initate a run-time while you earn more cash which you invest into companies again. You can either buy more companies of a type you already own (increasing the efficiency of income) or invest into new ones.

The heart of the game are actually the sidebars giving you new windows with different types of options. You can recruit managers which will at first "click" the bar for you opening up more time for you to do whatever you want with (checking statistics
hoursPlayed:
play another game). Later managers reduce purchase prizes of their comany type and so on.

Another bar provides access to general bonuses which you can purchase with either money or angels (more to this later). These can be things like doubling overall income or improve a specific company type.

Bonuses lists all milestones which will grant you huge bonuses so its something like a "roadmap" for you to work towards.

The universal fact about AdVenture Capitalist is that everything becomes obscenly expensive very soon forcing you to wait for upgrades while youe income accumulates until you can spend it again. Progression soon will become rather slow. The game continues running even if you are offline as it simply simulates the time gone by and adds the according income onto your tab. What it doesnt do for you is spend your money or invest into upgrades. Thats the "decision" part I mentioned earlier.

The "solution" if you will is not to let the game run but to direct the flow of money you earn in order to progress in an optimal way. You will always progress
voteText:
there is no way to "lose" the game or end up in a dead end but how quickly you do / how much time you spend until you hit another milestone depends on the decisions you make.

So there is a routine which becomes appearant quickly. A 2-side coin of spending money and waiting for it to generate until you can spend it again. We are not talking about mere millions here (even tho on your first run that can take a while as well) but SEPTSEXAGINTILLIONS.....dont ask me how many zeroes that are lol. Its safe to say that you ll soon move in a range of money that doesnt even exist in the whole world.

So we come to the core of the game. Percentages. How do you actually invest your money the "best possible way". Thats the actual challenge packed into a game. But the mechanics behind it can be found in everyday companies because its the wheels that turn the world. I guess any banker will have an immediate advantage at this thing :)

Instead of "waiting" for years of real time until you generate enough cash (thats how long it would actually take) the game implements several factors in order to speed up the process. These are the milestones
helpfulPercent:
bonuses and angels.



Milestone

can be checked under bonuses and show you what happens when you reach a certain number of a specific company. Hit 100 lemon stands and your income doubles or triples or your run-time reduces. Instead of going as high as possible you rather invest enough to unlock a milestone then focus on others in order to enhance your overall gameplay. Some milestones even affect all companies so checking constantly how far away you are from a milestone is well worth it.

You could invest 100 million dollars into car wash companies which would result in a hefty profit NOW but if you wait until you hit 110 millions and put them into lemon stands (resulting in much less profit if you break it down to a profit-per-dollar base) instead you ll reach a milestone making ALL your companies 2 times as profitable.

How you do the above example doesnt matter as you will reach it anyway but how LONG you ll spend of your time to reach it does difer.


Bonuses

start out low and slow but soon become the driving force of your game. These percentages do add up over time. Everybody who paid for a house and tried to pay the bank while doing so knows what I m talking about /grin. Theres a big list of bonuses to unlock so you ll be busy for a while trying to get them all.


Angels

These holy creatures are attracted by wealth and will accumulate over time. They dont do anything at first rather then watching you but you can always "claim" your Angels which will in effect soft-reset your game erasing all your money and deleting your companies. While before they were watching they are now "comitted" meaning they affect your work (the genre calls this "banked") throughout these soft resets. Each angel banked will increase your profit by 2%. Lets say you managed to accumulate 150 on your first runthrough that means that your NEXT run (even tho its the same in terms of gameplay) will be 3 times as fast.

Instead of making your game faster Angels ensure that you make more money in less time. So if your first million on your first playthrough took you roughly 10 minutes later on you ll generate this much with a single lemon stand on your first click because you have several BILLION Angels banked.



What follows is a combination of factors all playing together rising your income to really obscene levels. The routine is to go through the works in order to generate Angels.....soft-reset and reach your previously achieved money in LESS time. Your income rate increases this way but also do the prices of companies. Again decisions come into play. You could wait an hour for enough cash to generate in order to buy that next lemon stand or you could claim your angels NOW and be past this point in another hour.

Let me assure you

you will soft-reset many many times. Its actually the core mechanic in the game.


Once you become rich enough you ll have the option to go to the moon where the whole game starts again just with different factors and different mechanics (if you try to play the moon as you do the earth you ll fail hard = taking so long you ll lose any fun)



So lets come to the conclusion of this game.....whats actually fun about it or makes it worth playing?




This game is all about progression (like any other idle game as well). Not everybody will like it of course. The fact that you can start it

This game is a scam. I'm sad to say this because I did enjoy the game for a while. But I think like many people, I played the game for a long time before realizing that eventually you get to a point in which progressing is literally impossible.

I don't mean that progressing gets tedious and you're pretty much forced to choose between paying money for the game or doing something incredibly dull for a long time to feel like you didn't waste your effort getting to that point.

I mean that the game becomes literally unwinnable. You can't get all the achievements or in-game collectibles/purchases. Even if you pay real money on the game. Even if you spent over $1000 of the game, you will become literally unable to progress. Many people have done the math and it takes something like 30,000,000 years to complete the game. Of real-time. So unless you are immortal and honestly think this game is going to be around that long along with Steam and achievements, you're not going to finish it. Ever. And it seems like the developers are really reluctant to own up to this.

Many people have mental disorders or are just otherwise weak-willed and will get addicted to games like this and feel obligated to spend money. The fact that the developers make it so no matter what the game ends up impossible to progress and you can never reach your goals is just gross. They are well aware of the problem and just don't care. They make excuses and pretend like they'll eventually fix it but they never have. I can't express how horrible I think this is.

I don't care that it's free. Do not download this game.

reviewText:
How a funny, addictive game became utter trash. The story:

The early days of Earth were quite fun. You had progress, you had to think when to restart. You could easily f*k up your whole progress if you made a wrong angel investment for example. You had quick milestones, you had slow milestones. But at the end of the day, there was progress in terms of upgrading investment buildings and/or cash/angel upgrades.

Then the downfall. AdCap revealed it's true face. NO MONEY FOR US, NO PROGRESS FOR YOU. Hippo's new agenda headline.

I've made about 200 buildings progress on earth since they expanded all possible investments. Without any gold. That was months ago. No progress at all. It feels like there are either crucial cash upgrades missing or the new pricing system sucks.

Now for the precious, precious moon - it's funny in the beginning. Something new, somewhat different. But you soon realize that the adventure of investment progressing and stacking angels will suddenly come to an end. When hitting a certain threshold in buildings, all you do is waiting for angels - then reset to the exact same building threshold, just to reset again after a couple of days. Just a plain terrible experience compared to the original earth. It's basically angel farming while staying on the same amount of buildings for months.

So I thought I'd give gold upgrades a chance, and EVEN NOW, my moon income is terrible. Even with a 15x multiplier (around 7bucks in euro) it takes forever to gain angels. And I am not even remotely close to the next cash/angel upgrades or next building thresholds/mutliplier.

I came to the conclusion that this game (since the moon patch) is intended to rip you off as you basically have no noticeable progress at all, which ruins the fun. Even the ♥♥♥♥♥iest clicker games have noticeable, steady progress rise - but AdCap doesn't (anymore).

TL:DR - is fun at first with certain thresholds that take a long time, still a nice game to kill time with noticeable progress, later on becomes a pure pain in the ♥♥♥ once the extended content (new earth upgrades & the moon) is available.

I don't recommend this game. Even more if you plan to thank the developers with some real $$$. These guys don't deserve it.

This is not a pay some dollars if you want thinks a bit quicker".
This is "pay us dollars or you're never going to reach "the end" (in a lifetime).

STAY AWAY!"

reviewText:
Please stay away from this game.  In the current state, the game should be considered a scam and Steam should pull it until the developers fix Earth.  If you care to learn why I and so many other recent reviewers say this is a scam, please read my entire review and take some time to visit the Steam Discussions board.

It appears the developers unknowingly stumbled upon geese laying golden eggs.  But they had one problem...
“These damn geese keep completing the game and move on to lay their golden eggs elsewhere.”
“No more golden eggs?!?!”
“What to do?”
“Quick, come up with a fix, no matter how dishonest, unethical and sloppy!”
“We’ve got it, make Earth unbeatable!”
“Right, keep these stupid geese around a little longer by giving them useless updates to play. “

From what the developers have posted elsewhere, they were surprised by the fast success of this game and since people were finishing Earth within weeks, they came up with additional content in the form of additional Achievements on Earth and new planets in Moon and Mars.

They designed what was a fun and addictive idle clicker game but it is obvious they don’t know anything about actual game design/game play and are learning on the fly.  They released the same version of this game on all platforms and as the developers stated on the Steam board, they quickly discovered players using phones were checking in much more frequently than they had anticipated so they had to make it more difficult (longer waits) to get to the next Achievement.  This changed the balance of time needed between Achievements for those playing on tablets and computers as they checked in less frequently.

Eventually the whole thing got out of control on the Steam version.  Earth became so unbalanced that even if someone is willing to spend billions of real dollars to buy in-game gold, they could not complete Earth before our real sun burns out.  Some really smart people have done the math.  Math the game developers obviously never did when they increased wait times between Achievements.

Beyond the calculations, Steam players know for sure the game cannot be completed because the developers left the dev mode enable on the February update.  The same update, by the way, that wiped out many players progress.  Several fixes were immediately issued as the developers scrambled to make things right.  But a short time after shoring up those mistakes, they realized they made the February mini-game “For the Love of Money” too easy.  No problem for them, as they somehow adjusted game play, without an update and without notification, to reduce the number of Angel Investors players had earned.  Players that had earned Angel Investors on the first day the mini-game launched found their Angels reduced by half or more upon their next login.

I played the iPad version before the Steam version.  An October update screwed that version up by allowing players to earn Angel Investors at a much faster rate than they were supposed to.  By the time that version was fixed, most players, myself included, would need to let their games run several months without any Achievements for their lifetime earnings to catch-up to justify the number of Angel Investors they had been incorrectly given.
The entire situation is a mess and the developers, in a rare moment of honesty (or a brazen attempt to keep suckers in the fold), posted on the Steam Discussions board that they would issue an update to correct the problems with Earth, stating not doing so would be “unethical”.  Their word, not mine!  Five months after their proclamation, they continue to update the game, add new content and most importantly for them, add new ways to spend real money on a game they know cannot be completed.

If selling in-game gold with the promise it will help speed up a game that you imply can be finished when it in fact cannot be finished isn’t the definition of a scam, I don’t know what is then.

And one last comment.  Why have I and so many others wasted our time on this game?  Because the game was fun at the start and there was a set finish line.  Like a frog slowly boiling in water, unbeknownst to me the finish line was being pulled further and further away while the developers accepted my money.  Now I let the game run instead of deleting it in the hope that one day there will be an update allowing me to finish Earth.  I check-in every once in a while to see if anything has changed but do not play their monthly mini-games.  And I’m posting this review with the hope that I stop one person from wasting their time and money on Adventure Capitalist.

reviewText:
This is a pointless game, like most clickers, that goes on and on forever.  There is no actual end to it.  I suppose once you've completely maxed out every business it might end.  But this is not what actually even bothers me about this game.  What bothers me is that at a certain point, the game just comes to a screeching halt.

So you may be asking yourself, well, why is that?  Is she truly horrible at this game?  Perhaps.  But I will counter with a few comments on that.  First, there are many, many people who have used countless cheats and hacks trying to complete the achievements.  They still are unable to finish the game.  Second, some people better at math than I am have made some calculations and they figure that the game would take 10^18 years to complete without any cheating.  By that time, I highly doubt anything humans are doing, if they even still exist, will remotely look like what humans are doing now.  So unless some terrible B flick is to be made about some very distant ancestor finishing the quest to unlock the achievements is made, this just isn't going to happen.  Third, I have personally spent more money on premium upgrades (before I searched the internet to see where I was going wrong) than I am comfortable admitting to get over being stuck.  Even if I was terrible at the game, the amount of premium upgrades should have helped compensate for that.  I literally can load the game up, leave the computer to do dishes, use the restroom, take the trash out, and, if I'm very lucky, have seen the number change in the thousandths place by one or two digits.  Some people only check in on their game once a month and see minimal progress, if that.

So why hasn't anyone mentioned this to the developer?  Oh, they know.  They have been promising for many months to do something to help make the game playable again.  They have not done so.

On the up side, there are two unlockable planets, Mars and the Moon, that are totally completable without cheats, and a monthly event that lasts for around a week.

On the whole, I'd give this a 5/10.  The main portion of the game is truly broken at later levels that no amount of money seems to be able to fix.  But the two other planets and the monthly events are fun.  Play at your own risk.

reviewText:
This is a pointless game, like most clickers, that goes on and on forever.  There is no actual end to it.  I suppose once you've completely maxed out every business it might end.  But this is not what actually even bothers me about this game.  What bothers me is that at a certain point, the game just comes to a screeching halt.

So you may be asking yourself, well, why is that?  Is she truly horrible at this game?  Perhaps.  But I will counter with a few comments on that.  First, there are many, many people who have used countless cheats and hacks trying to complete the achievements.  They still are unable to finish the game.  Second, some people better at math than I am have made some calculations and they figure that the game would take 10^18 years to complete without any cheating.  By that time, I highly doubt anything humans are doing, if they even still exist, will remotely look like what humans are doing now.  So unless some terrible B flick is to be made about some very distant ancestor finishing the quest to unlock the achievements is made, this just isn't going to happen.  Third, I have personally spent more money on premium upgrades (before I searched the internet to see where I was going wrong) than I am comfortable admitting to get over being stuck.  Even if I was terrible at the game, the amount of premium upgrades should have helped compensate for that.  I literally can load the game up, leave the computer to do dishes, use the restroom, take the trash out, and, if I'm very lucky, have seen the number change in the thousandths place by one or two digits.  Some people only check in on their game once a month and see minimal progress, if that.

So why hasn't anyone mentioned this to the developer?  Oh, they know.  They have been promising for many months to do something to help make the game playable again.  They have not done so.

On the up side, there are two unlockable planets, Mars and the Moon, that are totally completable without cheats, and a monthly event that lasts for around a week.

On the whole, I'd give this a 5/10.  The main portion of the game is truly broken at later levels that no amount of money seems to be able to fix.  But the two other planets and the monthly events are fun.  Play at your own risk.
